body.p: Why is digital data, compared to analog, more resistant to noise?

multiple_choice.choice: Because anything plus 0 is unchanged, the digital signal resists errors.
Because anything multiplied by 1 is unchanged, the 1s are error resistant.
Because the digital form includes two copies of the data, there is always a backup copy to use.
Because even with lots of noise in the signal, it is relatively easy to distinguish the 0 from the 1.

feedback.p: It is true that anything plus 0 is unchanged, but that is not why digital signals are noise resistant.
This is true about multiplying by 1, but it is not the source of error resistance.
The digital form does not typically include two copies.
Since 0 and 1 are at the opposite sides, they are easy to distinguish even with lots of noise.
